1118541679877922816.text: It would be really fascinating if @EconTalker would invite David Ellerman to discuss inalienable rights, the property theory of labor, and democratic firms...

1118537675982684161.text: Simply because land is so extremely crucial and scarce that landlords, who monopolize it, can suck up most of the entrepreneur’s profits just by raising the rent.

1118537393680916481.text: If all the land in the urban center is owned by the rich, that’s an extremely limiting factor for the non-rich even if they are highly entrepreneurial, even if they could in principle build great companies with small initial capital.

1118536871439630336.text: Henry George, as far as I understand, points out that capitalists retain their power not just by exploiting labor, but even more so by buying the dominion over land, which prevents workers from accumulating their own capital?

1118534773092356096.text: As far as I can tell this is a viable solution for the question of the right relation between labor and capital. As for land, we probably need to bring up Georgism. Unimproved land value basically belongs to everyone—it is inalienable in a different way.

1118532801018716160.text: That would mean that the workers sign a contract with the investors to the effect of borrowing their capital in exchange for a share of future profits, which is what almost all investors really want. Workers rent capital without alienating their labor.

1118532325195829248.text: I think even venture capital investment is possible in an economic democracy, but the stocks owned by investors would just be financial derivatives of the firm’s profits—not voting tokens that appoint managers.

1118527475343142912.text: A spicy critique of Marxism along these lines is Ellerman’s “Marxism as a Capitalist Tool” (2010). http://www.ellerman.org/Davids-Stuff/Econ&Pol-Econ/MarxismAsACapitalistTool-reprint.pdf …

1118526752530345984.text: It also has a great advantage over Marxian anticapitalism or communism in that it is not only compatible with liberalism but comes right from the essence of it and corrects the illiberal errors of capitalism.

1118526203789492224.text: I like this theory because it refutes the most awful feature of capitalism, namely the inequitous control of production by absentee capitalists, without demonizing markets, competition, or private property.

1118523502783545350.text: An economy made of such democratic worker-owned cooperatives would attain “economic democracy.”

1118523114432937986.text: Instead of absentee firm owners renting workers to take their products, workers ought to be the firm owners, organize without alienating themselves, and share the profits.

1118522579168444417.text: While employment contracts are illegitimate, it’s entirely fine for people to sign contracts of collaboration that involve sharing incomes and liabilities. Thus the democratic firm.

1118522075570933761.text: Capital is alienable, because a tool is not a person, but personal liberty and responsibility cannot be alienated, so persons have to rent the capital in order to work for themselves.

1118521676453634049.text: Instead the only moral and fundamentally lawful organization is to have workers rent the use of capital (and land), essentially reversing the employment relation.

1118521203919028224.text: So Ellerman really does claim that employment contracts are basically void, an enormous fraud woven into the fabric of the world economy, which all ought to be phased out, thus cancelling the ability for firm owners to appropriate work products.

1118520685914206210.text: You just can’t use a person like you use a tool—that’s a moral axiom.

1118520310456881152.text: A person cannot voluntarily alienate the results of their work, because of de facto human nature. I am responsible for what I do regardless of any employment contract. I cannot sign a contract that turns me into a robot without responsibility.

1118519509202165760.text: David Ellerman makes a case for the inalienability of this right—and so for the illegitimacy of employment contracts. This is a critique of capitalism that doesn’t rely on a labor theory of value, but on a labor theory of property which is already part of basic liberal ideology.

1118518648602284033.text: But some rights are inalienable. Can a worker actually wholly alienate the right to their own labor products, or would that violate a natural right? A contract cannot legimitately (in liberalism) enslave one person, for example—the right to self-ownership is inalienable.

1118517906701262849.text: Lockean liberalism holds that each person owns the products of their own labor. But in “capitalism” workers cannot sell those products. They sign contracts that alienate the right to their own production, and get only wages.

1021069785629642759.text: The members’ shared experiences with open, internet based social platforms made them essentially skeptical of and disappointed with the less accessible social networks of politics.

1021069283458154498.text: The Pirate Party of Sweden took channeled energy from the collective joy of filesharing on p2p networks into a novel form of political party based on internet forums and a custom online voting and budgeting platform.

1021067772426575872.text: So the freedom to modify software and access to reliable blockchains become crucial to the flourishing of independent organization in this future.

1021066037717012481.text: What if free software with public blockchains give rise to new powerful organizational forms, alongside unions, parties, Twitter cabals, squatters, etc?

1021061474012233728.text: What if governmental contracts were visible as a stream of standardized transactions immortalized on an international ledger that anyone can verify?

Vampire Weekend sing: “Though we live on the U.S. dollar, you and me we have our own sense of time.”

Future lovers might sing: “Though we live on the public blockchain, you and me we have our own proof-of-love.”

1021054194105683969.text: In my imaginary future, blockchain is the paradigmatic concept for all formal social decisions. Transacting on a blockchain is the way you act “ritually” in the various virtual worlds that make up symbolic reality: trade, marriage, incorporation, taxation, and so on.

1021044594103013379.text: They tend to be interested in anthropological descriptions of the functions of currency, credits, and accounting, before the arrival of the titanic financial system we’re now in the shadows of.

1021042797082750977.text: The people I know in the blockchain underworld want to find concrete ways to create the conditions for better economy—by viewing economies as participatory social networks.

1021039910583787521.text: Blockchain is a possibly catastrophic fusion of peer-to-peer open social networks with the good old network of debt and property, the “cursed interdebtedness that will not do away with ledgers.”

1021039443224997889.text: If social media platforms mediate social reality, then we should play with their forms—“we still don’t know what our social networks can do.”
